questions.question: In the Rutherford gold foil experiment, what was the primary observation that led to the discovery of the atomic nucleus?
options: Most alpha particles passed through the foil with little to no deflection.
A small fraction of alpha particles were deflected at very large angles, including some that bounced straight back.
All alpha particles were absorbed by the gold atoms and re-emitted as light.
The gold foil became radioactive after being struck by the alpha particles.
questions.explanation: Rutherford: 'It was almost as incredible as if you fired a 15-inch shell at a piece of tissue paper and it came back and hit you.' ~1 in 8000 alpha particles deflected >90°, indicating small, massive, positively charged nucleus.

questions.question: According to Rutherford's model, the majority of an atom's mass is located in:
options: The electron cloud surrounding the center.
The empty space between the electrons.
A tiny, central region called the nucleus.
The orbiting alpha particles.
questions.explanation: Nucleus contains >99.9% of atom's mass but occupies ~$10^{-15}$ of its volume. Diameter: nucleus ~$10^{-15}$ m, atom ~$10^{-10}$ m. Electrons contribute negligible mass ($m_e/m_p \approx 1/1836$).

questions.question: Rutherford concluded that the nucleus must have a positive charge because:
options: It attracted the negatively charged alpha particles.
It repelled the positively charged alpha particles.
It contained only neutrons.
Electrons were found inside the nucleus.
questions.explanation: Alpha particles (+2e charge) repelled by nucleus → nucleus positive. Coulomb force: $F = k(Ze)(2e)/r^2$. Rutherford scattering formula explained angular distribution. Electrons discovered earlier (1897, J.J. Thomson).

questions.question: Which atomic model was directly disproved by the results of the Rutherford gold foil experiment?
options: The Bohr Model
The Quantum Mechanical Model
The Thomson 'Plum Pudding' Model
The Dalton 'Billiard Ball' Model
questions.explanation: Thomson's model (1904): electrons embedded in uniform positive 'pudding'. Would predict small-angle scattering only, not large-angle deflections. Rutherford's 1911 experiment required concentrated positive charge.

questions.question: If an alpha particle is moving directly toward the center of a nucleus, at its point of closest approach, its kinetic energy is:
options: At its maximum value.
Completely converted into electrostatic potential energy.
Zero, and all energy is lost as heat.
Equal to the mass of the nucleus.
questions.explanation: Energy conservation: $K_i + U_i = K_f + U_f$. At closest approach ($r = d$): $v=0$, so $K_f=0$. Then $K_i = U_f - U_i = k(Ze)(2e)/d$ (taking $U_\infty = 0$). $d = k(2Ze^2)/K_i$.

questions.question: What is the approximate ratio of the diameter of an atom to the diameter of its nucleus?
questions.explanation: Atom: ~$0.1-0.5$ nm ($10^{-10}$ m). Nucleus: ~$1-10$ fm ($10^{-15}$ m). Ratio: $10^4-10^5$. If nucleus = marble (1 cm), atom = football field (100-1000 m). Mostly empty space!

questions.question: Why did Rutherford use gold foil instead of another metal like aluminum or iron?
options: Gold is the only metal that can repel alpha particles.
Gold is highly malleable and can be hammered into extremely thin sheets.
Gold is a liquid at room temperature.
Gold attracts alpha particles more than other metals.
questions.explanation: Gold: can be made ~$0.6\ \mu\text{m}$ thick (~2000 atoms thick). Thin foil minimizes multiple scattering events. High atomic number (Z=79) increases scattering probability. Geiger & Marsden performed experiments (1909-1913).

questions.question: An alpha particle consists of:
options: One proton and one electron.
Two protons and two neutrons.
A high-energy photon.
A single isolated neutron.
questions.explanation: Alpha particle = $^4\text{He}^{2+}$ nucleus: 2 protons, 2 neutrons. Charge = +2e, mass ≈ 4 u. Emitted in alpha decay. Rutherford used alpha particles from radium source. Beta particles = electrons, gamma = photons.

questions.question: A limitation of the Rutherford model was its inability to explain why:
options: The nucleus was positive.
Orbiting electrons did not lose energy and spiral into the nucleus.
The atom was mostly empty space.
Alpha particles could be deflected.
questions.explanation: Classical electromagnetism: accelerating electrons (circular motion) radiate energy → spiral into nucleus in ~$10^{-12}$ s. Rutherford model unstable. Solved by Bohr (1913) with quantized orbits, later by quantum mechanics.

questions.question: If the initial kinetic energy of the incident alpha particles is increased, the distance of closest approach ($d$) to the nucleus will:
options: Increase
Decrease
Remain the same
Become zero
questions.explanation: $d = \frac{k(Ze)(2e)}{K_i} \propto 1/K_i$. Higher $K_i$ → smaller $d$. For 5 MeV alpha on gold (Z=79): $d \approx 4.6\times 10^{-14}$ m. Nuclear forces become important for $d < \sim10^{-14}$ m.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! Mastery of Rutherford's nuclear atom model including experimental evidence, scattering analysis, size/mass distributions, and historical context in atomic physics development.
scoreMessages.70: Very good! Strong understanding of Rutherford scattering. Review: 1) Experimental setup and observations, 2) Energy conservation for closest approach, 3) Comparison with Thomson model, 4) Scale of atomic vs. nuclear sizes, 5) Model limitations.
scoreMessages.50: Fair. Focus on: 1) Key results of gold foil experiment, 2) What large-angle scattering implies, 3) Nucleus properties (size, charge, mass), 4) Distance of closest approach calculation, 5) Why electrons don't collapse (classical problem).
scoreMessages.0: Start with basics: Review how Rutherford's experiment revolutionized atomic structure, proving atoms have tiny, dense, positive nuclei with electrons orbiting at relatively large distances.
